Knowing which gloves to (not) wear is an often neglected part of safety precautions. Often people just put on whatever gloves they have, ignoring that several common solvents, like DCM, will rapidly penetrate through nitrile and latex, and bring whatever was dissolved in them along for the ride. The tragic story of Karen Wetterhahn, who died after a drop of dimethylmercury just went straight through her gloves (and subsequently skin), is another example.

Pasivation occurs when strong and almost pure oxydizer acids come to contact with some metals. Here your almost pure HNO3 just forms Cu(NO)2 on the surface of the copper, but while your acid contains very little amount of water, this surface salt (which prevents acid to attack the core of the metal) can't dissolve (nitrite salts don't dissolve in pure HNO3, they need water) and let the surface ready to be attacked by HNO3, it's why the reaction slows down and "stops". If you add a little bit more water, you will make this nitrate salt layer dissolve immediately (all nitrites are very soluble in water) and the acid will be able to attack the core, it's why oxydizer acids attack metals much better in concentrated form than pure form. This passivation effect is much more strong with iron, aluminium, chrome, nickel, cobalt and other metals also.

In the Air Force back in the early 80's in Kansas I was tasked to watch a tanker loaded with Nitrogen Tetroxide (unsure of spelling?). The detail was called 'tank watch'. This tank watch took place at the missile silos, which surrounded Wichita Kansas. My job was simple...every hour I was to call in to the control center to report all is well topside with a loaded tanker trailer, filled with oxidizer(if in fact all was well ie: no leaks). Watching this video really drives home the idea that the Air Force was using me (and other young Airmen) as a sort of canary in the coal mine? I am so thankful to God that I never got hurt while in the Air Force. BTW in case your wondering, I was in the ELAB shop at McConnell AFB as a technician in the service of the Air Force. Normally my job was to maintain the electricals on the Titan II missiles and associated ground equipment. We used ampules of Nitrogen Tetroxide to calibrate the MSA (leak detection equipment), so I have seen and handled the red gas before🤪. Great video, I am amazed at your understanding of chemical reactions and processes.

Passivation is what allows fluorine gas to be stored in containers. It’s typically stored in nickel containers which have to be treated first before it can be used. First, a small amount of fluorine gas is let in, which scorches the nickel interior and converts a thin layer into nickel fluoride. The nickel fluoride protects the nickel below it which then allows the rest of the fluorine to be stored.

To make make explosives with nitric acid (benzene based) you need to mixed it with concentrate nitric acid and concentrate sulfuric acid.

It’s for the “electrophilic aromatic substitution” (EAS):

The sulfuric acid reacts whit the nitric acid to form a NO2+ kation and a HSO4- anion. A Benzene electron rich ‘pi-bound’ will react as an nucleophile and add NO2 to his hexane form and form a cyclohexadienyl kation.

HSO4- anion must react as an Brönstedt base and needs to eliminate a proton of the cyclohexadienyl kation to recover the aromatic form.

An alternative explanation to why copper did not react on the addition of fuming nitric acid is that such occurrence did not result from passivation but rather the difference in reactivity between molecular HNO3 and its ionic form in solution in water. The simple molecular HNO3 barely reacts at all with Cu. On addition of water the ions form, and HNO3 behaves like a "real" acid.

As someone who has done this...a few extra hints. Do use a vacuum, aspirator preferred. I use a recirculating system with a pump and a bucket of water with NaOH dissolved in it to eat any fumes etc. The reason is that the exotherm of the KNO3/H2SO4 reaction can go out of control and boil over into the rest of the rig. Stop the vacuum, wait a bit, you're good - safety, and not having to throw good glass (or quartz)ware out the window to save your lab.

The main reason RFNA is used is because it's hypergolic with some fuels and when stored correctly, stable. It means combinations like Hydrazine/RFNA can be kept in storage for years and still work correctly when used in things like altitude control thrusters for missles, as well as allowing such missles to remain stored in a fueled state without issue.

If you are going to make a kerosene/nitric acid fueled demonstrator, you might consider a hypergolic/pyrophoric starting slug. From my understanding, nitric/kerosene will not ignite well using a spark igniter in a motor, but if the fuel line to the combustion chamber is purged and primed with something like aniline, one of the hydrazines, or furfuryl alcohol in a burstable "capsule", the ingition is like turning on a hose, very smooth. Glushko used carbon disulfide dissolved in something (I can't remember what exactly, some kind of phosphorus), and another guy did it with diethylzinc. I wouldn't mess with TEA/TEB though. RFNA works great with aniline/hydrazine, but if using furfuryl, WFNA is best to avoid hard starts.

To my understanding the water in Nitric acid is whats dissolving the copper. This can be shown by simply adding a small amount of distilled water to high purity nitric acid after its added to copper. The copper metal is coated in an oxide layer and then sits there when 99%-100% acid is used, the moment a small amount of water is added it will dissolve. When it stops dissolving you can usually add a little more water to get a little more to dissolve

The way you detaimend the conzentration is somewhat flawed. With all the NOx dissolved its simply not working. The chart you found only works for Water/HNO3. Not for Water/HNO3/NOx. You can get a density that would correspond to >100% with such impurities like NOx or N2O5.
A better way to make the pure HNO3 is to mix H2SO4 with "dilute" HNO3 and simply destill it off, the water will mostly remain with the H2SO4.
Example: 1,8L 53% HNO3 + 1,5L conc. H2SO4, destillation stoped when mostly water comes over. This results in ~900mL ~85% HNO3 with little NOx. These 900mL mixed with 700mL conc. H2SO4 and stoping when the temperature starts to rise: 700mL >95% HNO3.
The H2SO4 is/can be dehydrated and used again as well as any remaining HNO3 coming out of it. Thus no waste und much purer HNO3.
To remove NOx is has to be destilled at reduced pressure.

Dr. Tim Root, an Ophthalmologist has a video where he demonstrates the effects of strong acid on the eye, and he also found that damage does not usually extend to the deeper layers. The eschar (dry charred area of skin formed after a burn) isn't easily attacked by acids, and their reaction will usually stop once it's formed, much like the passivation you encountered with the copper. He also repeated the experiment with a strong base and found that it attacked the eschar as its formed and will react until it's expended itself or makes it through the other end of the pig eye he was testing it on.

This video shows that the kid is being irresponsible with chemicals. Just one of his mistakes is not informing you to stay away from the nitric oxides produced during reactions. Passivation is a really interesting thing. You could do a whole video on how different materials actually stop corroding in the presence of stronger and/or more concentrated acids, oxidizers, etc. even though that seems counterintuitive. And I don't see any videos on Youtube that actually explore passivation chemistry in detail.

Here's an example you might consider using from us chemical engineers that's rather important in industry. A very common process from removing H2S and/or CO2 from gas streams is absorption with an amine such as MEA, DEA, or MDEA mixed with water. Amine plants are full of places with corrosion potential. You would probably expect H2S to be the bigger corrosion threat in the absorption column, but that's not actually true. It's usually CO2. Both of them react with the iron in the column which corrodes the steel. However, the iron sulfide layer formed from the H2S forms much quicker and adheres much more strongly than the FeCO3 layer from CO2. And once a solid FeS layer is formed, it actually protects the steel from further corrosion. So for H2S, we actually DESIGN the column to corrode and form that passivating FeS layer to PROTECT against further corrosion. With CO2, you have to take a completely different approach, because FeCO3 just continuously sloughs off, and you can lose a column much faster in the presence of CO2 because of that. Google "h2s passivation amine column" to read more.

Liquid propellants can be fairly tricky to use in a model engine...but with some work im sure you can pull it off. The issue is propellant pumping, thrilling and nozzle cooling. In your case pressurizing the propellant might be easiest and so both you fuel and oxidizer(Nitric Acid) reservoirs could be pressurized with some CO2 or preferably a inert gas.  The throttle would be secondary restriction valves to dial in the fuel mixtures flow. Since you only want to demonstrate, then you need to spray and mix in some order(this varies by design and fuel behavior) If the mixture is at all hypergolic your best mixing in the combustion chamber, if not you can premix and aerosol as single mixture. I can give you some design pointers if you like. But keep in mind it would be best to keep it simple and rough. Also material selection might be complicated by the nitric acid.
